Award.AwardTitle: Conjugated Organoboron Oligomers and Polymers: Functional Building Blocks for Supramolecular Structures
Award.AbstractNarration:
In this project funded by the Macromolecular, Supramolecular and Nanochemistry Program of the Chemistry Division, Frieder Jaekle of Rutgers University at Newark will use conjugated organoborane oligomers and polymers for the development of new rod-coil type amphiphiles, study their self-assembly into higher order structures, and probe their response to different chemical and physical stimuli. As a result of their electron-deficient nature, organoboranes offer a unique set of desirable features including strongly pi-accepting electronic properties and a pronounced tendency to form Lewis acid-base complexes. A diverse group of undergraduate and graduate students will be trained and high school students will be involved through the ACS project SEED. Their learning experience will be further enriched through international collaborations and student exchanges. As part of an effort to build bridges between research and undergraduate education a new experiment on conjugated polymers will be implemented in the Inorganic and Materials Chemistry undergraduate laboratory.

This work will generate new fundamental knowledge in the field of main group element chemistry and in the areas of conjugated polymers and supramolecular materials. Studying these types of conjugated polymers could lead to novel functional materials with characteristics beneficial to optical, electronic, and sensing applications.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University Newark
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
Conjugated oligomers and polymers are promising as new materials for plastic electronics, photovoltaics, electrochromic windows, charge-dissipating coatings, etc and in the broadly defined areas of biological and chemical sensors. Hybrid materials that feature main group elements such as boron (B), silicon (Si), or phosphorous (P) have also attracted much recent interest. As a result of its electron-deficient nature, boron in particular offers a unique set of desirable features including strong p-electron accepting behavior and a pronounced tendency to form complexes with anions and other electron-rich species. In addition, advantageous optical properties are often observed, such as strong absorptions in the visible region and intense photoluminescence. Our research under this grant was directed at the development of boron-containing conjugated oligomers and polymers with precise architectures and the ability to self-assemble into higher order structures. The self-assembly was expected to lead to novel functional materials with characteristics beneficial to optical, electronic, and sensory applications.

Specifically, we have (a) explored a new family of luminescent conjugated oligomers that consist of both triarylamine as electron-rich donor and triarylborane as acceptor units and uncovered the dependence of one- and two-photon absorption and emissions properties on the oligomer chain length; (b) developed organoborane oligomers and polymers for optoelectronics devices that contain more highly electron-deficient fluorinated borane building blocks and therefore exhibit even stronger electron-accepting character; (c) discovered a new type of luminescent borinic acid polymer that in DMSO shows solubility characteristics that can be varied by simple addition of small amounts of water; (d) developed a new type of luminescent triarylborane copolymer system that allows for detection of <1 ppm fluoride anions in aqueous solution. The project outcomes are documented in 12 peer-reviewed journal articles and 2 review articles; the results were broadly disseminated in more than 40 seminars and presentations at national and international conferences.

The grant enabled the training of 4 graduate students (two of them received their PhD degree), 3 postdoctoral researchers, and 5 undergraduate students. In addition, 2 minority high school students were provided with an opportunity to participate in the research program over the summer months. The educational component was further enriched by collaborations with colleagues in the US and overseas; the PI hosted students from Turkey and Japan. As part of an effort to build bridges between research and undergraduate education the PI developed a new experiment on conjugated polymer synthesis and their optical and electronic properties and implemented it in the “Inorganic and Materials Chemistry” undergraduate laboratory in the Spring of 2013. Finally, the PI organized a 3.5 day conference at Rutgers University-Newark “Boron in the Americas” that attracted 90 researchers from over 10 different countries.


Last Modified: 10/04/2014
Modified by: Frieder Jaekle
